title: Top 100 Most Searched Items on Amazon
content:
Curious to know what online shoppers are looking for on Amazon? 

Then this article is for you.

What Are the Most Searched Items on Amazon?

In the U.S., the most searched item on Amazon is “apple watch,” followed by “crocs” and “airpods.” 

Amazon’s “kindle” comes next.

We discovered this using Semrush’s now-retired Keyword Wizard for Amazon app. Which had one of the biggest Amazon keyword databases.

We used this database to uncover the most searched items. And we’ve compiled them into a handy list that you can reference.

Let’s take a look at the complete list.

Note: These lists are based on U.S. data that was pulled in July 2023.

As you can see, Apple products are in demand. This highlights the brand's strong appeal and customer loyalty.

There’s also high demand for items such as “crocs,” “ps5,” and “kindle.” Which indicates diverse consumer preferences.

How to Find What’s Trending on Amazon

Amazon has a few useful pages that give you an idea of what’s trending on the platform.

Amazon Best Sellers page: You’ll see the most popular products across multiple categories. And the page is updated frequently.
Amazon Movers & Shakers: This page shows products that have gained popularity in the last 24 hours
Amazon Most Wished For: This page shows the most popular items on people’s wish lists. And is updated daily.

You can also use Product Research Pulse to find Amazon products. This app provides ecommerce insights from major retailers to show you the top-ranking products for certain keywords.

Use the "Identify Keywords" option in the app (under the “Solutions” drop-down), then sort the list by best seller rank. 

You can then analyze each product deeper with the "Analyze Product" button.

If you’re a seller on Amazon, consider adding similar products to your inventory to capitalize on these trends.

Unlock Amazon Insights

with Product Research Pulse

Try for Free →
How to Find Amazon Keywords

Amazon sellers should optimize their product listings with the business-related keywords people are searching for.

This will make their products more discoverable on the platform. And generate more sales.

But how do you find these keywords?

One way is to use Semrush's Organic Research tool. This tool analyzes a website's organic search performance and identifies its top-ranking keywords.

Here's how to use it for Amazon:

Open Semrush's Organic Research tool and enter "amazon.com" in the search bar. 

Click, "Search."

Click the "Positions" option in the menu.

Then, enter your seed keyword in the search bar. And click the magnifying glass to search.

For example, Amazon.com ranks in Google's top 100 pages for 166 search queries that include the phrase "vitamin D gummies."

Scroll down to see the list of keywords. Analyze the results to find relevant keywords for your Amazon listings

If you’re a new seller on Amazon, it’s probably best to target keywords that are easier to rank for. And incorporate them into your product titles and descriptions to improve discoverability.

Find Keywords to Optimize Your Amazon Listings

with Organic Research

Try for Free →
Conduct Extensive Keyword Research

Identifying which keywords people search for on Amazon is a good start. But don’t stop there.

Amazon is just one of many platforms online shoppers visit.

If you also sell products via your own ecommerce store, knowing what keywords people search for on Google is equally important.

You can target these keywords with the product and category pages on your website. And achieve higher Google rankings.

Open Semrush’s Keyword Magic Tool and enter a broad keyword that describes your business. 

Then, click “Search.”

You’ll see keywords that can potentially bring lots of Google traffic to your website.

Use these keywords in your title tags, meta descriptions, and URLs. And follow all the other on-page SEO best practices. For high rankings and more traffic.

Get Keyword Suggestions for Your Website

with the Keyword Magic Tool, the Biggest Keyword Database on the Market

Try for Free →
